answer: <p>Just change the url to <code>http://localhost</code> instead of <code>localhost</code>. If you open the html file from local, you should create a local server to serve that html file, the simplest way is using <a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/web-server-for-chrome/ofhbbkphhbklhfoeikjpcbhemlocgigb?hl=en" rel="noreferrer"><code>Web Server for Chrome</code></a>. That will fix the issue.</p>

<p>In an Android app  for example, to allow JavaScript to have access to assets via <code>file:///android_asset/</code>  use <code>setAllowFileAccessFromFileURLs(true)</code> on the <code>WebSettings</code> that you get from calling <code>getSettings()</code> on the <code>WebView</code>.</p>

<p>If you use Mozilla Firefox, It will work as expected without any issues; </p>

<p>P.S. Surprisingly, IntenetExplorer_Edge works absolutely fine!!!</p>

<p>I was getting this exact error when loading an HTML file on the browser that was using a json file from the local directory. In my case, I was able to solve this by creating a simple node server that allowed to server static content. I left the code for this at this <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/a/26845720/267835">other answer</a>.</p>
<p>It simply says that the application should be run on a web server. I had the same problem with chrome, I started tomcat and moved my application there, and it worked.</p>

<p>er. I just found some official words "Attempting to load unbuilt, remote AMD modules that use the dojo/text plugin will fail due to cross-origin security restrictions. (Built versions of AMD modules are unaffected because the calls to dojo/text are eliminated by the build system.)" <a href="https://dojotoolkit.org/documentation/tutorials/1.10/cdn/" rel="nofollow">https://dojotoolkit.org/documentation/tutorials/1.10/cdn/</a> </p>

<p>One way it worked loading local files is using them with in the project folder instead of outside your project folder. Create one folder under your project example files similar to the way we create for images and replace the section where using complete local path other than project path and use relative url of file under project folder .
It worked for me </p>

<p>Experienced this when I downloaded a page for offline view. </p>

<p>I just had to remove the <code>integrity="*****"</code> and <code>crossorigin="anonymous"</code> attributes from all <code>&lt;link&gt;</code> and <code>&lt;script&gt;</code> tags</p>
<p>If your using VS code just trying loading a live server in there. fixed my problem immediately.</p>
data.title: "Cross origin requests are only supported for HTTP." error when loading a local file
data.content:
<p>I'm trying to load a 3D model into Three.js with <code>JSONLoader</code>, and that 3D model is in the same directory as the entire website.</p>

<p>I'm getting the <code>"Cross origin requests are only supported for HTTP."</code> error, but I don't know what's causing it nor how to fix it.</p>
